commit_message:
Optionally configure Ceph RGW listener with SSL

In order to have ssl for the ceph rgw component, this
review adds the steps needed to generate the key/cert
if the related condition is true.
This patch also adds all the elements to make the cert
request using tls-e framework.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/703743
Co-Authored-By: Francesco Pantano <fpantano@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I85b855fdf2bd14f497862bddf46b0f205058d7d5
(cherry picked from commit 232079894d3cc970d896c561755df55277fbdb3a)

subject: Use more permissive regex to remove the offending 127.0.1.1
messages: [{'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-03-06 17:06:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch stable/stein.'}, {'account_id': 22629, 'date': '2020-03-10 07:31:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 30523, 'date': '2020-03-10 10:35:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-06 17:06:31.000000000', 'message': "Use more permissive regex to remove the offending 127.0.1.1

line from /etc/hosts

Ubuntu always uses 127.0.1.1 for that with some tricky sauce
around `hostname` depending on whether it contains '.' or not.
And when I mean `hostname` it's the one returned by `hostname`
command with no arguments.

ansible_hostname is always a single word so we can match on that.

I did not want to remove just any 127.0.1.1 in case someone
is using it for other purposes. :-)

Change-Id: I8bd3d42a5e3bd0f63336ed60a0af90d52b1650d6
Closes-bug: #1862739
(cherry picked from commit adbe115e39ef2320e2e1ab57f97d5191282951d7)
(cherry picked from commit ac158d19f5d0b5085b8c2fb2ba17cebd164f6582)
"}]
commit_message:
Use more permissive regex to remove the offending 127.0.1.1

line from /etc/hosts

Ubuntu always uses 127.0.1.1 for that with some tricky sauce
around `hostname` depending on whether it contains '.' or not.
And when I mean `hostname` it's the one returned by `hostname`
command with no arguments.

ansible_hostname is always a single word so we can match on that.

I did not want to remove just any 127.0.1.1 in case someone
is using it for other purposes. :-)

Change-Id: I8bd3d42a5e3bd0f63336ed60a0af90d52b1650d6
Closes-bug: #1862739
(cherry picked from commit adbe115e39ef2320e2e1ab57f97d5191282951d7)
(cherry picked from commit ac158d19f5d0b5085b8c2fb2ba17cebd164f6582)

commit_message:
Fix logging call in the segment plugin

Arguments should be separate, not a tuple, else we'll
get a traceback.

Change-Id: I142fa1119c15076708a64991adfe30cb8ce38ea3
Closes-bug: #1865098

commit_message:
Small cleanups

Setup.cfg:
- This repo is python 3 only ,remove universal wheel building.
- Remove pbr.hooks.setup_hook, those are obsolete since a long time

tox.ini:
- remove tox:jenkins, this is not used since ages

Change-Id: Ia6c1bc28b4935859c29924141965f47c4bcbd2c3

commit_message:
Enable Ussuri and Focal

Make db migration optional and Train only and update OVN service
plugin entry point for Ussuri.

Add tactical workaround for LP: #1864640

To allow running lint on a Python 3.8 system (Focal), unpin
flake8.

Clean up test-requirements.txt and mock out dependencies rather
than installing them in the unit test virtualenv.

Func-Test-Pr: https://github.com/openstack-charmers/zaza-openstack-tests/pull/187
Change-Id: I8d291e35b1bc52332c4666584277eb41c88ef084

commit_message:
Remove Python 3-specific conditional in dump_as_bytes

Now that we only support Python 3 we don't need logic to handle
Python 2.

Change-Id: I33747d25bc4c67ee13654ed132edf7413371c1dc

commit_message:
overcloud: set DeployIdentifier to '' if --skip-deploy-identifier is used

Similar to Ib1928b60ba7b03983f303577a53df078d32d2b1b, ensure that
DeployIdentifier is empty if --skip-deploy-identifier is used.

Change-Id: I1eaa845bfc18b1c77e8463582ee13c173b62bb38
Related-Bug: #1866135

DeployIdentifier needs to be empty if --skip-deploy-identifier is used
otherwise a new identifier is generated and the --skip-deploy-identifier
feature doesn't work, as Puppet and Ansible will be executed on all the

Closes-Bug: #1866135
Change-Id: Ib1928b60ba7b03983f303577a53df078d32d2b1b

commit_message:
deployment: set DeployIdentifier to '' if --skip-deploy-identifier is used

DeployIdentifier needs to be empty if --skip-deploy-identifier is used
otherwise a new identifier is generated and the --skip-deploy-identifier
feature doesn't work, as Puppet and Ansible will be executed on all the
nodes.

Closes-Bug: #1866135
Change-Id: Ib1928b60ba7b03983f303577a53df078d32d2b1b

commit_message:
Provide a foundation for purely out-of-band deploy/clean steps execution

For manual cleaning we need to be able to execute steps without booting IPA.
For deployment we need to be able to execute out-of-band steps before
booting IPA the first time. This change updates the relevant functions
to be able to opt-out of receiving in-band steps.

Story: #2006963
Change-Id: I3ffc4682f378322503a06c6247144e2bcf1df29d

[{'created': '2020-01-27 17:18:11.000000000', 'message': 'Update ffwd-upgrade branch names

The next iteration of fast-forward-upgrade will be
from queens through to train, so we update the names
accordingly.

We also set the default values to all base the list
from a single variable to deduplicate them, making
the list easier to maintain in the future.

commit_message:
Deduplicate ffu release lists

We can set the default values to all be based on
a single variable to reduce the maintenance burden
just a little.

Change-Id: I2f034213bacc9931a9a6c813e7e7b0443a552899

commit_message:
Fix RabbitMQ hostname address resolution precheck

Make it require uniqueness of resolution as well to avoid later
issues with RabbitMQ going crazy.

Change-Id: I000ba6c62ab44eac0abdf8d5d1f069adfbc6552f
Closes-bug: #1863363

(2 comments)

This spec needs a lot more detail. I'm not actually sure what is being proposed here? Is the idea to create a local "proxy" volume on the nova-compute host that uses SSDs to perform caching of all IO that then gets sent through to the actual volume? How does that work if they run something like LVM on the same host as nova-compute.

I would think there would need to be changes on the nova side to support this as well? Or is the idea that os-brick would just take care of everything and nothing would look different to nova or whatever the consuming service is for the volume? How does os-brick know to even attempt to do something like this?

Please elaborate on what you are planning so someone reading this spec can understand how the different pieces will fit together to support the end goal.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-10-17 13:10:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Impact to cinder appears to be really low with just needing to recognize the extra spec and disallow some operations.

os-brick changes are a little more involved, but like pointed out, nothing too different than what we are already doing with encryption. So I wouldn't expect that to be a huge challenge.

This looks good to me. It matches what I remember discussing at the Shanghai Summit. It would be good to move this forward."}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2020-01-14 20:36:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(42 comments)

In my opinion we should be able to do this on our own in os-brick, without Nova telling us to use the cache on a per volume basis.

What do you say to have the volume manager add the cacheable key to the connection information when we initialize the volume and then have os-brick automatically create the cache device?

As I see it it would be something like:
- Nova calls os-brick get connector info telling it the cache configuration so it can be passed to cinder.
- Nova calls cinder with the connector info to initialize the connection, and cinder adds the cacheable key to the connection info returned by the driver based on the volume type, and it also adds the cache info that nova provided in the connector info.
- Now os-brick, when it is told to attach the volume will check if the cache keys are there and if it's not encrypted it will automatically do the cache stuff internally after the attach, and if it is encrypted it will do it after the decryption.

If the volume is cacheable, but there is no cache enabled in nova, os-brick will be able to issue a warning.

This method has the benefit of having fewer changes to Nova, although there would be more changes in os-brick.

PS: the downvote is only for using cachable instead of cheable"}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-01-14 21:01:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: -Code-Review

Limiting the scope of changes needed sounds good if we can do that. Waiting to hear further discussion.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2020-01-14 21:27:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

The downvote is for the questions I have just added to the previous patch.'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2020-01-15 15:28:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)

This needs more info on how it interacts with cinder/nova operations:
    - Is caching done after data is encrypted, when using encrypted volumes?  (It has to be, so that decrypted data is not written to storage.)
    - How do cinder snapshots work?  There seems to be no mechanism to ensure that the desired data has been flushed to a volume when a snapshot is requested.
    - How is live migration of instances/volumes handled?
    - Is this used when performing image->volume copies?  Backups?
    - What are the implications for multipath?  (Which some deployments rely on for image->volume.)
    - Consistency groups?

How does it compare to alternatives such as enabling the writeback cache in Nova/qemu for volume attachments?

How do we handle selecting the right cache tool if we support more than one in Cinder later?  Can more than one be used on a deployment?  Can a deployment change from using open-cas to a different cache layer on existing volumes?'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2020-01-15 15:29:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Also, what happens when attaching cinder volumes to ironic nodes?'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2020-01-15 15:30:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11347, 'date': '2020-01-16 01:58:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-01-16 08:56:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

(10 comments)

Thanks for your reviews.

- Is caching done after data is encrypted, when using encrypted volumes?  (It has to be, so that decrypted data is not written to storage.)
[LiangFang] For performance purpose, the order may should be: user - cache - encryption - backend storage. If cache behind encryption, encryption would be the bottleneck. Currently the volume encryption itself is done in host OS via dm-crypt, so guest OS need to trust host OS I think.

- How do cinder snapshots work?  There seems to be no mechanism to ensure that the desired data has been flushed to a volume when a snapshot is requested.
- How is live migration of instances/volumes handled?
[LiangFang]
write-through: no problem, because full data is in backend storage at any moment, no need to flush data.
write-back: yes, it cannot work. Dirty data may be in cache.

- Is this used when performing image->volume copies?  Backups?
[LiangFang]
image->volume: glance image to cinder volume? volume should not be attached to any VM at this moment, right? Cache only in compute node, similar to Linux memory buffer for volumes that mounted to the host OS. I think it works.
Backups: volume to volume, and happened in cinder side, right? I think write-through works, but write-back not work.

- What are the implications for multipath?  (Which some deployments rely on for image->volume.)
[LiangFang] If by pass cache, trying to write data to a backend volume that already attached to a VM, it would be problem, because the data in cache would be out-of-date. So multipath is not allowed.

- Consistency groups?
[LiangFang]
write-through: works
write-back: not work

- How does it compare to alternatives such as enabling the writeback cache in Nova/qemu for volume attachments?
[LiangFang] my understanding is:
qemu: can only use DRAM as cache, so cache size cannot be very large. 
I think qemu can well handle live migration. But still cannot correctly handle the operations did outside of qemu, e.g. in cinder side, take snapshot, the volume would not contains full data, because some dirty data is in qemu memory.

- How do we handle selecting the right cache tool if we support more than one in Cinder later?  Can more than one be used on a deployment?  Can a deployment change from using open-cas to a different cache layer on existing volumes?
[LiangFang]
Yes, it is flexible to change to other cache tool, because no specific cache related data is written to the backend volume.
open-cas(write-through) just like Linux system DRAM buffers, it cache for volumes, but will not change any thing to the volume.
os-brick accepts cache name and cache parameters(e.g. cache instance IDs) from nova. So it's flexible to use different cache software in different compute node. See: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/663549/3/os_brick/caches/__init__.py

- what happens when attaching cinder volumes to ironic nodes?
[LiangFang] I think it would not work for ironic nodes, because cache is expected to happen outside of VM."}, {'account_id': 11347, 'date': '2020-01-17 03:29:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-01-17 04:22:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11347, 'date': '2020-01-17 06:03:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Though I would like to have multiple cache software co-working on a certain compute host because different backends may choose to use different caching mechanisms (this proposal does not support that), I think you should at least be explicit about it in both the nova and cinder specs.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2020-01-20 15:43:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

I want to step back and take a look at the overall design of this feature.

Cinder needs to be able to say whether a volume-type is 'cacheable' or not because some backends cannot make use of the proposed caching scheme, and because some volume-types (e.g., multiattach) should not use caching.

The advantage of the open-CAS scheme is that it's transparent and doesn't require any special formatting of the volume.  So a 'cacheable' volume could be attached to a hypervisor that has a local volume cache or doesn't have a cache--it doesn't matter to the volume.  Whether the volume makes use of caching or not depends on the HV it lands on.

Further, all the cache management and configuration (e.g., choice of available cache modes) is done independently of Cinder.  So I think it makes sense to make the choice of whether to use a HV with a local volume cache part of VM selection, e.g., by offering a server flavor with a local volume cache.  The end user decides whether the volume will be cached or not by selecting the flavor.  If there's no room on a suitable HV to create the VM, the user's in the same situation we have now when a server-build request can't be satisfied, so users should be able to deal with this already.

This also allows for asymmetrical use cases where, e.g., you need really fast write throughput while collecting data, but don't need such fast read throughput when analyzing the data.  If 'cacheable' volumes are only attachable to VMs on HVs with a local volume cache, the economical-minded end user has to keep retyping the volume for an asymmetrical use case.  Further, an operator has to maintain a 'cacheable' and noncacheable version of each volume-type, which seems like a lot of work for little gain.

This gets even worse if the cache-mode is tied to the volume type.  The operator has to maintain a volume type for each of the cache-modes offered, and an end user who wants to change cache modes has to retype the volume.

So how should the cache mode be selected?  I don't know, but I think that conceptually it is *not* a volume property and shouldn't be included in the volume type.

If the selection of cache mode is moved to the nova side, then it's not clear that os-brick needs to get a cache-mode-map to figure out how to connect a volume.  Nova can just tell os-brick which cache instance to use, and whether this is just pulled from a config file, or is part of a flavor, or something in the server-build request can be decided later.  It shouldn't matter to os-brick.

I think this would make the nova spec simpler, since we'd have a path from a simple implementation that simply makes a local volume cache available on some HVs to something more complicated later that could take into account offering different cache modes, etc."}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-01-21 07:26:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-01-21 07:36:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Thanks Brian, agreed, and spec updated based on this.
1) "cacheable" property only means the volume is eligible to be cached, not must be cached. "eligible" means: not set with multiattach, supported by backends(e.g. NFS/ceph not support), etc
2) Nova tries to schedule the VM to a node with cache capability, but it should not fail it if target node lack of the cache capability, Nova should let the VM go ahead without cache.'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-01-21 09:49:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 11347, 'date': '2020-01-22 02:15:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

I can not speak on behalf of nova, however IMHO from nova's point of view, we try to avoid this ambiguity. End user will get confused if he booted up 2 VMs with the same flavor and got significant volume performance differences only because one VM landed on a server with cache software and the other didn't.

 > 2) Nova tries to schedule the VM to a node with cache capability,
 > but it should not fail it if target node lack of the cache
 > capability, Nova should let the VM go ahead without cache."}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-01-24 08:40:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2020-01-27 13:42:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Does anything need to be done with the cache to handle an attached volume that is extended?  Does the cache need to account for the change in size?'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2020-01-30 19:46:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-01-31 13:10:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-01-31 13:31:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

(2 comments)

Thanks Eric for your comments. Some replied in spec, some here:
When an attached volume resized, what I saw was: the volume would be detached and then re-attached. I think it is the necessary step, otherwise even file system / volume encryption laying on the resized volume would not work correctly.

Does anything need to be done with the cache to handle an attached volume that is extended?
[Liang] don't need. volume detach and then re-attach is enough for cache re-mapping.

Does the cache need to account for the change in size?
[Liang] yes. but after volume detach and then re-attach, a brand new cache emulated device is created. e.g. /dev/cas1-1 with old size is removed when detach, but /dev/cas1-2 with the new size is created when re-attach. So it doesn't matter."}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-01-31 14:10:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-01-31 14:17:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 18.'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2020-01-31 18:37:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18: Code-Review-1

I left a suggestion inline, let me know what you think.'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-02-01 04:28:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 19.'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-02-01 04:40:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 19:

3) I realized Eric's comments makes sense, an encrypted volume should put security at top. Spec updated. Thanks all."}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2020-02-07 09:51:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 19:

I think all the points that have come up in discussion so far have been addressed.  I've got a question inline about handling backends that can do discard/trim (following up on Eric's question on PS15), but I don't think we need to hold the spec up for that.

As discussed at today's cinder meeting, we envision the implementation happening in 3 phases:
(1) feature considered experimental in Ussuri
(2) support added to devstack to deploy open-cas so tempest tests can be run with the volume-local-cache enabled
(3) feature finalized in Victoria"}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-02-20 03:01:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-February/012669.html

There were no replies, so this spec is approved.  Thanks for all the work you've done on this, Liang."}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-03-10 10:41:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 22:

@rosmaita
regarding TRIM/Discard, I got answer from open-cas TL:
------------------------------------------
When CAS receives TRIM/DISCARD request it removes corresponding data from cache (without flushing if dirty). This prevents flushing and occupying cache space by data that is discarded by app/fs and would no longer been using.
Next, if backend storage supports TRIM/DISCARDS it sends trim request down do backend storage.
------------------------------------------

So TRIM/Discard works well as usual and transparent, we don't need to modify any code for it."}]

[{'created': '2019-09-25 08:21:38.000000000', 'message': 'Support volume local cache

Add the support of cache software that caches remote slow volume using
fast local SSD.

commit_message:
Support volume local cache

Add the support of cache software that caches remote slow volume using
fast local SSD or persistent memory.

Related Nova spec:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/689070/

Change-Id: I4d6e44789ece9accda2044dbf31bbf8f8393fbd2
Signed-off-by: Liang Fang <liang.a.fang@intel.com>

commit_message:
Fix RabbitMQ hostname address resolution precheck

Make it require uniqueness of resolution as well to avoid later
issues with RabbitMQ going crazy.

Change-Id: I000ba6c62ab44eac0abdf8d5d1f069adfbc6552f
Closes-bug: #1863363
(cherry picked from commit 5dd9c532c6a9df6de30ad22169fdecd0a613201f)

- allow role user to add extra commands to run
- tests feature
- documents feature

[{'created': '2020-02-20 15:25:42.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: test the gate

'}, {'created': '2020-02-25 12:00:31.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: test the gate

Change-Id: I0a798e5ab92ad079e070c577360147ab8980bf0a
'}, {'created': '2020-03-02 12:37:51.000000000', 'message': 'Fix gate failure

When creating a tox env, networking-bgpvpn train version is installed.
It has a dependency of horizon<17.0.0 (train) which requires Django<2.1
and it is not compatible with u-c and horizon ussuri. It leads to a tox
creation failure. We need to install ussuri version of networking-bgpvpn.
A beta1 of networking-bgpvpn has been released, so we can use it.

This patch is based on https://review.opendev.org/708829 from amotoki,
again thanks to him.

Change-Id: I0a798e5ab92ad079e070c577360147ab8980bf0a

commit_message:
Fix gate failure

When creating a tox env, networking-bgpvpn train version is installed.
It has a dependency of horizon<17.0.0 (train) which requires Django<2.1
and it is not compatible with u-c and horizon ussuri. It leads to a tox
creation failure. We need to install ussuri version of networking-bgpvpn.
A beta1 of networking-bgpvpn has been released, so we can use it.

neon release of ODL is no more available as snapshot, but as a released
so the neon functional job was changed to use latest release instead of
a snapshot.

This patch is based on https://review.opendev.org/708829 from amotoki,
again thanks to him.

Change-Id: I0a798e5ab92ad079e070c577360147ab8980bf0a

parameters.

commit_message:
Use "name:" instead of "role:" for *_role modules

Both include_role and import_role expect role's name to be given
via "name" param instead of "role".
This worked but caused errors with ansible-lint.
See: https://review.opendev.org/694779

Change-Id: I388d4ae27111e430d38df1abcb6c6127d90a06e0

subject: timeout cni-daemon request handler workers
messages:
[{'account_id': 28082, 'date': '2019-12-12 03:04:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28082, 'date': '2019-12-12 03:08:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 23567, 'date': '2019-12-13 08:53:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Based on the bug explanation... This seems more like a workaround rather than a solution. IMO, if we have a livelock we should try to identify where it is and fix it'}, {'account_id': 23567, 'date': '2019-12-13 08:53:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Adding -1 just to ensure the comment is not missed and discuss about it'}, {'account_id': 28082, 'date': '2019-12-13 09:57:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Based on the bug explanation... This seems more like a workaround rather than a solution. IMO, if we have a livelock we should try to identify where it is and fix it

You are right, it is a workaround for the actual bug. But we've seen that it is useful to have a stopgap measure to kill workers in a reasonable time (This also helps with graceful exit of daemon). 

Also, I'd like to point that the CNI binary anyway times itself out and sends a failure response to kubelet, so leaving the worker active after that timeout it not very useful."}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2019-12-19 08:54:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

The only reason for the deadlock I can see would be from the usage of multiprocessing.Manager - maybe a deletion from dict hangs or something like this.

Also *maybe* it might be related to `semaphores` argument on the `lock()` context manager:

    :param semaphores: Container that provides semaphores to use when locking.
        This ensures that threads inside the same application can not collide,
        due to the fact that external process locks are unaware of a processes
        active threads.

No idea if that might be related, I cannot find a direct link but we do run this from different processes.

In general it makes total sense to me to timeout requests. Do you know what's the kubelet's CNI timeout? I'm also a bit surprised that there is no timeout parameter on `oslo_concurrency`. This solution isn't pretty, but should work in general. It might be worth to add some comments to _before_request() to explain what it does."}, {'account_id': 28082, 'date': '2020-03-10 06:36:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}]
revisions:

Implement timeout for all requests received by the cni-daemon.
In rare cases, some workers were observed to be stuck waiting
forever for locks. This timeout ensures that all requests are eventually
terminated.

Signed-off-by: Yash Gupta <y.gupta@samsung.com>

commit_message:
timeout cni-daemon request handler workers

Implement timeout for all requests received by the cni-daemon.
In rare cases, some workers were observed to be stuck waiting
forever for locks. This timeout ensures that all requests are eventually
terminated.

Partial-Bug: 1856107
Change-Id: Ife32c0b32d41e0cb5c6a3273fa2181cf3a88a090
Signed-off-by: Yash Gupta <y.gupta@samsung.com>

commit_message:
Fix RabbitMQ hostname address resolution precheck

Make it require uniqueness of resolution as well to avoid later
issues with RabbitMQ going crazy.

Change-Id: I000ba6c62ab44eac0abdf8d5d1f069adfbc6552f
Closes-bug: #1863363
(cherry picked from commit 5dd9c532c6a9df6de30ad22169fdecd0a613201f)

Remove python_2_unicode_compatible usage

Since we don't support Python 2 anymore, we don't need
to use python_2_unicode_compatible decorator.

subject: Support processing only for pods with CNI ADD
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 11600, 'name': 'Michał Dulko', 'email': 'mdulko@redhat.com', 'username': 'dulek'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23567, 'name': 'Luis Tomas Bolivar', 'email': 'ltomasbo@redhat.com', 'username': 'ltomasbo'}, {'_account_id': 25900, 'name': 'Vladimir Kuramshin', 'email': 'vladimir@kuramsh.in', 'username': 'vkuramshin'}, {'_account_id': 27032, 'name': 'Maysa de Macedo Souza', 'email': 'maysa.macedo95@gmail.com', 'username': 'maysa'}, {'_account_id': 28082, 'name': 'Yash Gupta', 'email': 'y.gupta@samsung.com', 'username': 'y.gupta'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 28082, 'date': '2019-11-29 06:26:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23567, 'date': '2019-11-29 08:50:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Thanks for bringing this up. Not sure if this is a bug or missing functionality though. Anyway, 2 thigs:
1) We need to update documentation related to how kuryr works if we are adding a new communication cni -> controller, while previously it was only controller -> cni
2) There is a plan to move pods annotations to have 'ports' CRD objects instead. Perhaps this could be part of that effort and modify the flow slightly to have:
a) when a pod is created, the cni detects it and create the port CRD object (empty, like a request)
b) the kuryr controller detects the new CRD and performs the neutron calls and updates the status of the port CRD object with neutron port information
c) kuryr-cni reads (watchss) that information from the port CRDs.

Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 28082, 'date': '2019-11-29 08:55:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> 1) We need to update documentation

Agreed, let's do that once we settle on the implementation

> 2) There is a plan to move pods annotations to have 'ports' CRD objects instead

I really like this approach, and it looks more elegant too. Are there any existing patches for moving to CRD?"}, {'account_id': 28082, 'date': '2019-11-29 08:57:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

While it is a almost a new feature, there was some discussion related to this at https://bugs.launchpad.net/kuryr-kubernetes/+bug/1681338

If you feel I should register a blueprint instead, that should be fine too'}, {'account_id': 28082, 'date': '2020-03-10 06:12:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-29 06:26:35.000000000', 'message': 'Support processing only for pods with CNI ADD

In multi-cni environments, some pods may not use kuryr as a CNI. In
such cases, controller should not create neutron ports for it
(these ports will never bind and might even leak neutron resources)

A config option in [kubernetes] section, process_after_cni_add is
added which can be set to true to only process a pod after a
CNI ADD request is received for it.

As it uses a label on the pod to communicate this information to
the controller, it has a small overhead which might not be
desirable in environments with kuryr as the only CNI.

Closes-Bug: 1681338
Change-Id: Icf21a6b10fe64abe7ff0d5ed3470bdf008cdf437
Signed-off-by: Yash Gupta <y.gupta@samsung.com>
'}, {'created': '2020-03-10 06:12:11.000000000', 'message': 'Support processing only for pods with CNI ADD

In multi-cni environments, some pods may not use kuryr as a CNI. In
such cases, controller should not create neutron ports for it
(these ports will never bind and might even leak neutron resources)

As it uses a label on the pod to communicate this information to

Signed-off-by: Yash Gupta <y.gupta@samsung.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Support processing only for pods with CNI ADD

In multi-cni environments, some pods may not use kuryr as a CNI. In
such cases, controller should not create neutron ports for it
(these ports will never bind and might even leak neutron resources)

A config option in [kubernetes] section, process_after_cni_add is
added which can be set to true to only process a pod after a
CNI ADD request is received for it.

As it uses a label on the pod to communicate this information to
the controller, it has a small overhead which might not be
desirable in environments with kuryr as the only CNI.

Closes-Bug: 1681338
Change-Id: Icf21a6b10fe64abe7ff0d5ed3470bdf008cdf437
Signed-off-by: Yash Gupta <y.gupta@samsung.com>

[{'created': '2020-01-17 15:24:34.000000000', 'message': 'Remove global state from the FakeDriver

The virt driver FakeDriver used in both the functional and in the unit
test used a global state to configure the host and node names the driver
reports. This was hard to use when more then one compute service is started.
Also global state is dangerous.

It turned out that only a set of unit tests are using multiple nodes per
compute the rest of the tests can simply use host=<hostname>,
nodes=[<hostname>] setup.

So this removes the global state.

On stable/stein:
* Changes in functional/regressions/test_bug_1764556.py just removes the
  usage of the global state as that test was backported before the patch
  being backported was introduced

* Changes in functional/regressions/test_bug_1839560.py is a re-backport
  of If822509e906d5094f13a8700b2b9ed3c40580431 adapted to the current
  patch.

Related-Bug: #1859766

Change-Id: I2cf2fcbaebc706f897ce5dfbff47d32117064f9c
(cherry picked from commit b5666fb49239dbed6777481be63276db35ed8118)
'}]
commit_message:
Remove global state from the FakeDriver

The virt driver FakeDriver used in both the functional and in the unit
test used a global state to configure the host and node names the driver
reports. This was hard to use when more then one compute service is started.
Also global state is dangerous.

It turned out that only a set of unit tests are using multiple nodes per
compute the rest of the tests can simply use host=<hostname>,
nodes=[<hostname>] setup.

So this removes the global state.

On stable/stein:
* Changes in functional/regressions/test_bug_1764556.py just removes the
  usage of the global state as that test was backported before the patch
  being backported was introduced

* Changes in functional/regressions/test_bug_1839560.py is a re-backport
  of If822509e906d5094f13a8700b2b9ed3c40580431 adapted to the current
  patch.

Related-Bug: #1859766

Change-Id: I2cf2fcbaebc706f897ce5dfbff47d32117064f9c
(cherry picked from commit b5666fb49239dbed6777481be63276db35ed8118)

commit_message:
Add CAA record type support

This commit adds the CAA record type in the list of editable record
types of the Designate Dashboard. This fixes existing CAA records being
shown without a record type, and allows users to create and update
CAA records.

Change-Id: I8287f3f8879592b385852c83007d4b46a61a55c7
Signed-off-by: Aggelos Kolaitis <akolaitis@admin.grnet.gr>

commit_message:
Set ignore_basepython_conflict in tox

Ida03f9cca7d276ed8a449d21c0ba58330916e7d9 defined
the basepython in common place but
did not set the ignore_basepython_conflict to True
in tox to avoid the wrong version in py env and
error in future.

Change-Id: I398df150ebf6e5ec9bc34344f0f95a6eb2d0244d

commit_message:
baremetal provision expose concurrency and timeout

These arguments are available in the workflow but are not exposed as
arguments. This change fixes that, allowing users to tune for their
environment.

The new ansible version of this command already has these arguments
(next change in this series)

Change-Id: I00b224ec7e2334afd2dfe549f36dbec2987a1be1

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

heat-tempest-plugin is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Stable zuul jobs are modified to run with py3 as heat-tempest-plugin
cannot run py2 jobs on master gate.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: Ida6919a70dc8711166a79eac574b0714382e8d00

'}, {'created': '2020-02-14 02:25:52.000000000', 'message': 'Add ensure-venv element, install glean with it

All the platforms we care about now have python3 with venv (even
centos7 now) packaged somehow.  Add an ensure-venv element to make
sure that "python3 -m venv" works.  Any other elements that wish to
install non-distribution-packaged Python utilities can use this to
keep them separate from the main system installs.

Port glean to use this, and drop its dependency on pip-and-virtualenv.

Change-Id: Ic16f134fe34293bb68e7c632dd320f523366320d
'}, {'created': '2020-03-06 01:57:30.000000000', 'message': 'Add ensure-venv element, install glean with it

sure that "python3 -m venv" works.  Any other elements that wish to
install non-distribution-packaged Python utilities can use this to
keep them separate from the main system installs.

Port glean to use this, and drop its dependency on pip-and-virtualenv.

Change-Id: Ic16f134fe34293bb68e7c632dd320f523366320d

commit_message:
Add ensure-venv element, install glean with it

All the platforms we care about now have python3 with venv (even
centos7 now) packaged somehow.  Add an ensure-venv element to make
sure that "python3 -m venv" works.  Any other elements that wish to
install non-distribution-packaged Python utilities can use this to
keep them separate from the main system installs.

Port glean to use this, and drop its dependency on pip-and-virtualenv.

Change-Id: Ic16f134fe34293bb68e7c632dd320f523366320d

commit_message:
nova process not disable

Nova process name in failue process notification usually is not
exactly 'nova-compute', it need to reset the process name for
later recovery workflow.

Change-Id: I1dbac2a3acf370c195cae5433ebabdb93f489f29
Close-Bug: #1858757

commit_message:
Not process port security groups twice

Add a new cache set for ports which were just processed as
'added' in last rpc loop cycle. Then skip processing their
security group again in current loop. This is a first step
of not-process-port-twice. A simple cache can not work
for all port processing functions, since there is a case
that port can be processing as "added" while the server
side is changing some attribute like QoS. In the next rpc
loop it should be processed again.

Closes-Bug: #1841865
Change-Id: Ie7c3220407f08d45e5388e9aacc7fec257409914

If a user specifies a header in their request for metadata,

behalf. Make sure to remove any headers we don't want, and
override something that might be present in the request.

commit_message:
Remove extra header fields in proxied metadata requests

If a user specifies a header in their request for metadata,
it could override what the proxy would have inserted on their
behalf. Make sure to remove any headers we don't want, and
override something that might be present in the request.
If the agent somehow gets a request with both headers it will
silently drop it.

Change-Id: Id6c103b7bcebe441c27c6049d349d84ba7fd15a6
Closes-bug: #1865036
(cherry picked from commit 5af046fd4e6387cdbf8bf65ea4c2039a4019b64b)

[{'created': '2020-03-04 22:23:40.000000000', 'message': 'Fix upload-swift-artifacts handling of json data

The upload-swift-artifacts script needs to handle json encoding of
the Temp-Url-Key property, and [1] was a step in the right direction.
However, it contained two errors that this patch corrects:

1. The property name is "Temp-Url-Key" (camel-case). Even if you specify
   "Temp-URL-Key" something will change "URL" to "Url". This patch uses
   the correct form when detecting whether the property exists.

2. The logic for detecting whether the Temp-Url-Key property exists was
   inverted. The property doesn't exist when the jq output is "null".

[1] Ife347f754ca9129580c092bb271bacdc032ae14b

Change-Id: Idf0dccf4cd7d040e803b2ed2b49b3c39919c5a60
'}]
commit_message:
Fix upload-swift-artifacts handling of json data

The upload-swift-artifacts script needs to handle json encoding of
the Temp-Url-Key property, and [1] was a step in the right direction.
However, it contained two errors that this patch corrects:

1. The property name is "Temp-Url-Key" (camel-case). Even if you specify
   "Temp-URL-Key" something will change "URL" to "Url". This patch uses
   the correct form when detecting whether the property exists.

2. The logic for detecting whether the Temp-Url-Key property exists was
   inverted. The property doesn't exist when the jq output is "null".

[1] Ife347f754ca9129580c092bb271bacdc032ae14b

Change-Id: Idf0dccf4cd7d040e803b2ed2b49b3c39919c5a60

commit_message:
test_kolla_builder: make tests invariant to default data

anytime there are changes to namespace/tag/ceph related default
values a number of unittest changes also have to be made.

This hints that we are over-constrained on our unittests.

- Remove the hard-coded entries for defaults from the file
- template out the images to be removed from the list
- pass in a few more parameters to test_container_images_from_template
- build up dictionary with data from CONTAINER_IMAGES_DEFAULTS to
  compare against in test_container_images_template_inputs

commit_message:
Cleanup tasks for container-puppet.py

- When Paunch is disabled, don't create container-puppet.py and if the
  file exists, make sure we remove it so operators don't run it by
  accident.
- Remove the reference of that script from the README and the commands,
  to make it clear there is a new tool now.

Change-Id: I5032eef6567b37c02fe53dea852aadff3e185eec
(cherry picked from commit bfb8b2b7fddb8aaaed6579cfa3bf3d6e13d0dec3)

commit_message:
Fix hypervisors paginted collection_name.

Hypervisor view builder's _collection_name,
'hypervisors' is used to build next link that
sdk use as uri to do paginated query. But correct
API should be `GET /v2.1/os-hypervisors?<params>`
rather than `GET /v2.1/hypervisors?<params>`.

This patch fixes this bug.

Change-Id: Idc4f3fe54136a6bd3dbc7dc0efd3f62745991199
Closes-Bug: 1864428
Signed-off-by: Fan Zhang <zh.f@outlook.com>
(cherry picked from commit b68033ecc9d38dcbe339c993338bdca691f73b33)

commit_message:
Fix minor error in extarq job

The patch fix the var need_job init value to False,
In some case, The None will cause some errors that
are not easy to be detected.

Change-Id: Ic4eac2fbc274fc5dfe9b2f4b796888b96bd78d0c
Story: 2007352
Task: 38932

commit_message:
Set --no-user-install in gem install

Since --user-install was enabled by default in gem[1], we need to set
--no-user-install to make "gem install" refer GEM_HOME.

Closes-Bug: #1866176
[1] https://github.com/rubygems/rubygems/pull/2847

commit_message:
Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

trove-tempest-plugin is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/691178/

Change-Id: Id689113d1cca11f27cee7598b841e365225b50df

prints five parameters, none of them the security group rules. In

commit_message:
Include "fields" to "SecurityGroup" query parameters

This new query parameter will allow to send a query sending the
"fields" parameter. This "fields" parameter contains the needed
OVO fields that need to be retrieved from the DB.

As commented in the related bug, the OS client "list" command only
prints five parameters, none of them the security group rules. In
systems with a reasonable amount of security groups, skipping the
unnecessary rule load can save a lot of time.

Change-Id: Ifa5af28e76bf6017fc6cd1dbd998efbe0e1200bf
Related-Bug: #1865223
(cherry picked from commit b3068002da8798e75d9c9a98fbc40fde1f68fdfe)

'}, {'created': '2020-02-23 23:35:22.000000000', 'message': 'Uncap hacking

This causes problems for other projects incorporating dib; we don't
have a specific need for a cap.

Fix a few issues, mostly spacing or regex matches.  No functional
changes.

W503 and W504 relate to leaving artithmetic operators at the start or
end of lines, and are mutually exclusive and, due to "ignore"
overriding the defaults both get enabled.  It seems everyone gets this
wrong (https://gitlab.com/pycqa/flake8/issues/466).  Don't take a
position on this and ignore both.

Use double # around comments including YAML snippets using "# type: "
which now gets detected as PEP484/mypy type hints.

Change-Id: I8b7ce6dee02dcce31c82427a2441c931d136ef57
'}]
commit_message:
Uncap hacking

This causes problems for other projects incorporating dib; we don't
have a specific need for a cap.

Fix a few issues, mostly spacing or regex matches.  No functional
changes.

W503 and W504 relate to leaving artithmetic operators at the start or
end of lines, and are mutually exclusive and, due to "ignore"
overriding the defaults both get enabled.  It seems everyone gets this
wrong (https://gitlab.com/pycqa/flake8/issues/466).  Don't take a
position on this and ignore both.

Use double # around comments including YAML snippets using "# type: "
which now gets detected as PEP484/mypy type hints.

Change-Id: I8b7ce6dee02dcce31c82427a2441c931d136ef57

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-08 02:35:28.000000000', 'message': 'Remove all ignore_errors to avoid confusion when debugging

- octavia_controller_post_config: remove "ignore_errors: true". It's not
  supposed to be needed, since there is already a
  "failed_when: config_contents.rc != 0" which knows when to fail.

- octavia_undercloud, tripleo_cellv2, tripleo_ceph_common,
  tripleo_container_manage, tripleo_packages and tripleo_puppet_cache:
  replace "ignore_errors: true" by "failed_when: false" for debugging
  experience. We know the tasks can fail and we don't care, let's just
  not show them as failures in that case and force the task to never
  fail.

- tripleo_podman: instead of ignoring errors, check if the config file
  actually exists before wipping it out.

Change-Id: Ib3716e4823735a9db9bd3cac33b8daf0e5f3d186
(cherry picked from commit c1959707db82c558886eba4389069d3e22abada9)
'}]
commit_message:
Remove all ignore_errors to avoid confusion when debugging

- octavia_controller_post_config: remove "ignore_errors: true". It's not
  supposed to be needed, since there is already a
  "failed_when: config_contents.rc != 0" which knows when to fail.

- octavia_undercloud, tripleo_cellv2, tripleo_ceph_common,
  tripleo_container_manage, tripleo_packages and tripleo_puppet_cache:
  replace "ignore_errors: true" by "failed_when: false" for debugging
  experience. We know the tasks can fail and we don't care, let's just
  not show them as failures in that case and force the task to never
  fail.

- tripleo_podman: instead of ignoring errors, check if the config file
  actually exists before wipping it out.

Change-Id: Ib3716e4823735a9db9bd3cac33b8daf0e5f3d186
(cherry picked from commit c1959707db82c558886eba4389069d3e22abada9)

commit_message:
[WIP][RFC] Refactor the join list snippet

There seems to be desire to add variance to the list join function. Instead
of creating new ones with minor variance, this patchset provides a generalize
version. Existing methods should rely on this new generic function and marked
deprecated. Existing functions are left to avoid breaking existing usage.

Change-Id: I86463ac464ba82c3adb5e5e14bedfd3765b7e94a
Signed-off-by: Tin Lam <tin@irrational.io>
Co-Authored-by: Steven Fitzpatrick <steven.fitzpatrick@att.com>

commit_message:
Revert "Add neutron-ovs-cleanup to neutron charts"

This reverts commit 09d6a3e68c3d95e27ce7a7395735d058062e9d17.

It causes failures during brown field upgrade.

Improve unit test coverage in octavia::controller

Add missing tests for octavia::controller so that we can test all
parameters with their default values and overridden values.

[{'created': '2020-02-12 11:44:52.000000000', 'message': 'Add ovs/igmp_snooping_enable support

This patch is adding support to the "ovs/igmp_snooping_enable"
configuration option in the neutron.conf and ml2_conf.ini configuration
files.

Both, ML2/OVS and ML2/OVN reuse the same configuration option to enable
IGMP but, for ML2/OVN this option could can be set in the neutron.conf
(since it will be consumed on the controllers) and and for ML2/OVS it's
configured for the agents (ml2_conf.ini)

commit_message:
Add ovs/igmp_snooping_enable support

This patch is adding support to the "ovs/igmp_snooping_enable"
configuration option in the neutron.conf and ml2_conf.ini configuration
files.

Both, ML2/OVS and ML2/OVN reuse the same configuration option to enable
IGMP but, for ML2/OVN this option could can be set in the neutron.conf
(since it will be consumed on the controllers) and and for ML2/OVS it's
configured for the agents (ml2_conf.ini)

Change-Id: I1d96899de29cdd994f2a45b701923b0177a7edd8
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

messages:
[{'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2020-03-08 17:55:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2020-03-09 08:30:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2020-03-09 10:12:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

How is possible that this feature (n-lib and neutron patches) was not properly tested? We had almost all the code but the extension was neither added nor tested.'}, {'account_id': 21798, 'date': '2020-03-09 11:33:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Indeed it was not at correct place, for reference:
https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/6144bbf9c28a9d2678fdb5db5e2c45d731d29f94/neutron_lib/api/definitions/floating_ip_port_forwarding.py#L74'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2020-03-09 13:14:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Fix definition of the fip_pf_description api extension

In this extension "description" field should be added in the
SUB_RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP rather than in RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP.
It also should be added in "parameters" dict which is inside
SUB_RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP.

Change-Id: Ifcb0d81eafe65696401954055b9d29b36d2d397a
Related-Bug: #1866560

commit_message:
Revert "Remove warning message when using old and new engine facade"

Partial revert. We made a mistake including this log message every
time this condition happens. Now the Neutron server debug logs are
polluted with this message.

This reverts commit 77b761dfe438f7a2d61dac3337b65d0f9d85c20b.

Change-Id: I86366a151f132d59f250368e4e206509c1a45d3d

commit_message:
Add accepted egress direct flow

Do not flood the packets to bridge, since we have the
bridge port list, we can add a simple direct flow to
the right port only.

Conflicts:
	neutron/agent/linux/openvswitch_firewall/firewall.py
	neutron/conf/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovs_conf.py
	neutron/tests/unit/agent/linux/openvswitch_firewall/test_firewall.py
	neutron/tests/unit/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/agent/openflow/native/test_br_int.py

Closes-Bug: #1732067
Related-Bug: #1841622
Change-Id: I14fefe289a19b718b247bf0740ca9bc47f8903f4
(cherry picked from commit efa8dd08957b5b6b1a05f0ed412ff00462a9f216)

commit_message:
Add VLAN type conntrack direct flow

For vlan type network, we add a segment match flow
to the openflow security group ingress table. Then
the packets will be recorded in conntrack table, and
the reply packets can be processed properly.

Conflicts:
	doc/source/contributor/internals/openvswitch_firewall.rst

Change-Id: Ieded0654d0ad16235ec923b822dcd842bd7735e5
Closes-Bug: #1831534
(cherry picked from commit aa58542e823d23d233524cd5639c7ec4bb757769)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-25 10:06:11.000000000', 'message': 'ovs agent: signal to plugin if tunnel refresh needed

Patch https://review.opendev.org/#/c/697655/ cannot be backported
because it includes an RPC version change. This patch is for the
stable branches.

Currently the ovs agent calls update_device_list with the
agent_restarted flag set only on the first loop iteration. Then the
server knows to send the l2pop flooding entries for the network to
the agent. But when a compute node with many instances on many
networks reboots, it takes time to readd all the active devices and
some may be readded after the first loop iteration. Then the server
can fail to send the flooding entries which means there will be no
flood_to_tuns flow and broadcasts like dhcp will fail.

This patch fixes that by also setting the agent_restarted flag if
the agent has not received the flooding entries for a network.

Change-Id: Iccc4fe4a785ee042fd76a663d0e76a27facd1809
Closes-Bug: #1853613
(cherry picked from commit bc0ab0fcd721d3fb01fd83291269a586f50efa0e)
(cherry picked from commit aee87e72b1d456da66d719ccf19054ac1f285a7b)
(cherry picked from commit d1e2b840b57ba9425d5ea710a0509b677eefcc08)
(cherry picked from commit 576e76f209ce69d99606ce126cfd4a96d99f8e88)
'}]
commit_message:
ovs agent: signal to plugin if tunnel refresh needed

Patch https://review.opendev.org/#/c/697655/ cannot be backported
because it includes an RPC version change. This patch is for the
stable branches.

Currently the ovs agent calls update_device_list with the
agent_restarted flag set only on the first loop iteration. Then the
server knows to send the l2pop flooding entries for the network to
the agent. But when a compute node with many instances on many
networks reboots, it takes time to readd all the active devices and
some may be readded after the first loop iteration. Then the server
can fail to send the flooding entries which means there will be no
flood_to_tuns flow and broadcasts like dhcp will fail.

This patch fixes that by also setting the agent_restarted flag if
the agent has not received the flooding entries for a network.

Change-Id: Iccc4fe4a785ee042fd76a663d0e76a27facd1809
Closes-Bug: #1853613
(cherry picked from commit bc0ab0fcd721d3fb01fd83291269a586f50efa0e)
(cherry picked from commit aee87e72b1d456da66d719ccf19054ac1f285a7b)
(cherry picked from commit d1e2b840b57ba9425d5ea710a0509b677eefcc08)
(cherry picked from commit 576e76f209ce69d99606ce126cfd4a96d99f8e88)

commit_message:
Relex python3 version for pep8

Running tox -epep8 on ubuntu 18.04 fails. Because
ubuntu 18.04 seems does not have a python3.5. I
think it is safe to relax the constraints and use
whatever python3 available.

Change-Id: I26c4ca0a789ade852e409dabad41814380fda0da

commit_message:
Clean up allocation if unshelve fails due to neutron

When port binding update fails during unshelve of a shelve offloaded
instance compute manager has to catch the exception and clean up the
destination host allocation.

Conflicts:
  nova/compute/manager.py due to I59aec72e158eb2859bb6178b2a42d3f3438ab0f3
  is missing in stein

Change-Id: I4c3fbb213e023ac16efc0b8561f975a659311684
Closes-Bug: #1862633
(cherry picked from commit e65d4a131a7ebc02261f5df69fa1b394a502f268)
(cherry picked from commit e6b749dbdd735e2cd0054654b5da7a02280a080b)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-20 13:50:09.000000000', 'message': "Set instance CPU policy to 'share' through image property

Before the introduce of 'CPU resource', a 'cpu_policy' of None
is same as a 'cpu_policy' of 'shared' effectively.

But these two CPU policies ('shared' and None) have some difference now,
checking the code in 'hardware.numa_get_constraints', if the variable
'cpu_policy' is not set, which means 'cpu_policy==None', it still possible
to get the instance CPU policy through the setting of 'resources:VCPU' and
'resources:PCPU'.

We should return the 'cpu_policy==shared' if 'hw_cpu_policy==share' and
'hw:cpu_policy' is not defined. Otherwise, if you want to set a 'shared'
policy through 'hw_cpu_policy', but it might be alerted by the setting
of 'resources:PCPU'.

Change-Id: I0e2d90d83180e91c3217f5a806a48e518ab235e8
Closes-Bug: #1848308
(cherry picked from commit 569ad1402e2447ef72672934947541c81b3d5ef7)
"}]
commit_message:
Set instance CPU policy to 'share' through image property

Before the introduce of 'CPU resource', a 'cpu_policy' of None
is same as a 'cpu_policy' of 'shared' effectively.

But these two CPU policies ('shared' and None) have some difference now,
checking the code in 'hardware.numa_get_constraints', if the variable
'cpu_policy' is not set, which means 'cpu_policy==None', it still possible
to get the instance CPU policy through the setting of 'resources:VCPU' and
'resources:PCPU'.

We should return the 'cpu_policy==shared' if 'hw_cpu_policy==share' and
'hw:cpu_policy' is not defined. Otherwise, if you want to set a 'shared'
policy through 'hw_cpu_policy', but it might be alerted by the setting
of 'resources:PCPU'.

Change-Id: I0e2d90d83180e91c3217f5a806a48e518ab235e8
Closes-Bug: #1848308
(cherry picked from commit 569ad1402e2447ef72672934947541c81b3d5ef7)

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC

service + deployment pairs

commit_message:
Add Helm Charts for MetaController and DaemonJobController.

These charts bootstraps a metacontroller on a
Kubernetes cluster using the Helm package manager.
This enables you to deploy custom controllers as
service + deployment pairs. A DaemonJobController
chart bootstraps the CompositeController and register
DaemonJob CRD, the daemonjob controller executes
DaemonJob(CR's) in kubernetes Cluster.

Change-Id: Ic946f564ea1cf07e89c90a598e59230dc240950c

commit_message:
Forces root for get_ssh_private_key

The ssh private key is not created by the external tasks so we
need to use become: true to make sure external tasks have read
permissions on the file.

Change-Id: Ic88ccee05c5a286763661e8cc97e75b13dedba7e
Related-Bug: 1823229
(cherry picked from commit ccc8fb2e4864bfcb2ba2db63e4cf360c51c46d0d)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-04 16:57:05.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Ignore DiskNotFound during update_available_resource

There was a previous attempt to fix this in
change Id687e11e235fd6c2f99bb647184310dfdce9a08d. However, there were 2
problems with the previous fix:

1. The handling of missing volumes and disks, while typically having the
   same cause, was inconsistent.

2. It failed to consider the very wide race opportunity in
   _get_disk_over_committed_size_total between initially fetching the
   instance list from the DB and later getting disk sizes.

Because _get_disk_over_committed_size_total() can be a very long
operation, we found that we were reliably hitting this race in CI.
It might be possible to fix the race, but this would add unnecessary
complication to code which isn't critical. It's far more robust just to
log it and ignore it, which is also consistent with the handling of
missing volumes.

Closes-Bug: #1774249

Change-Id: I48719c02713113a41176b8f5cc3c5831f1284a39
(cherry picked from commit 6198f317be549e6d2bd324a48f226b379556e945)
(cherry picked from commit 73d9b6e5f622dc645ac6ad322c836ffbe4045072)
"}]
commit_message:
libvirt: Ignore DiskNotFound during update_available_resource

There was a previous attempt to fix this in
change Id687e11e235fd6c2f99bb647184310dfdce9a08d. However, there were 2
problems with the previous fix:

1. The handling of missing volumes and disks, while typically having the
   same cause, was inconsistent.

2. It failed to consider the very wide race opportunity in
   _get_disk_over_committed_size_total between initially fetching the
   instance list from the DB and later getting disk sizes.

Because _get_disk_over_committed_size_total() can be a very long
operation, we found that we were reliably hitting this race in CI.
It might be possible to fix the race, but this would add unnecessary
complication to code which isn't critical. It's far more robust just to
log it and ignore it, which is also consistent with the handling of
missing volumes.

Closes-Bug: #1774249

Change-Id: I48719c02713113a41176b8f5cc3c5831f1284a39
(cherry picked from commit 6198f317be549e6d2bd324a48f226b379556e945)
(cherry picked from commit 73d9b6e5f622dc645ac6ad322c836ffbe4045072)

For centos-8 it is epel/8/Everything/x86_64 an c7 it
epel/7/x86_64/.

Add overcloud update converge role

Adds tripleo_overcloud_update_converge to run the update converge step.

commit_message:
add debug for swapfile mount status

at times the swapfile is failing because it's
claiming it's already mounted. Add a little
debug in a block to help users see the facts.

Change-Id: I81279704be806d4cf2afe52379e2398f5f068a4e
Partial-Bug: #1865174

commit_message:
Removal of deprecated command and deprecated optional argument

lib/tempest uses 'tempest-account-generator'
which is deprecated 4 years back.
In addition to above, lib/tempest also uses
'os-tenant-name' which is also deprecated.

Use of 'tempest account-generator' and
'os-project-name' should be done now.

Signed-off by: Soniya Vyas<svyas@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I624e1dc57a3d3533322fb298c01f70241d0400ed
(cherry picked from commit 7634c780027ad05e416c2a0c5ac688751aba4be6)

commit_message:
Add grafana vip on the storage network

This patch allows us to make sure we set
the ceph_grafana_vip on the storage network
since it's not the service that should be
exposed to the end users.

Change-Id: I7728b6a6bbf8447ec3290a13cb7f5807b30cc01f
(cherry picked from commit 7b97d50ff4e884b24b3e66538b5999290cebed76)

[{'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2019-12-15 11:12:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 29963, 'date': '2019-12-15 11:14:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Please rebase the change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2019-12-15 11:23:00.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to bug/1756118'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-12-15 13:42:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded.

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/699115/1 : SUCCESS in 2h 27m 34s'}, {'account_id': 17685, 'date': '2020-01-09 16:44:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Clean cherry-pick, merged to master. According to bug report this needs to be backported until queens, so looks ok to me.'}, {'account_id': 22076, 'date': '2020-01-21 09:10:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2020-01-21 12:15:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

i dont agree with the premiss that if you use host passthough then checking compatiablity does not matter.

we want the live migration to be prevented before we try to do the migration to prevent doing as much work as possibel if its going to fail. when using host-passtough it is more important to do this check as it is more likely that it will fail. i dont think this should be backported and i would sugges we should revert this on master.'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2020-01-21 12:18:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

> i dont agree with the premiss that if you use host passthough then
 > checking compatiablity does not matter.
 > 
 > we want the live migration to be prevented before we try to do the
 > migration to prevent doing as much work as possibel if its going to
 > fail. when using host-passtough it is more important to do this
 > check as it is more likely that it will fail. i dont think this
 > should be backported and i would sugges we should revert this on
 > master.

Can you propose the revert and give that justification there? I'll -W this until that's resolved one way or another."}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2020-01-21 12:55:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/703596/1 i was just doing that

at a minium i think we should be adding a workaround config option to opt into this behavior so that when libvirt finally fixes this we dont have to revert the code but i also think we can do at least a partial check unless for compatibility as we can compare the cpu feature flags.

looking at the output of the domain capablities api we do not get back alot of useful info but we can at least check the gic version compatiblity and likely the machine type.

<domainCapabilities>
  <path>/usr/local/bin/qemu-system-aarch64</path>
  <domain>qemu</domain>
  <machine>virt-4.1</machine>
  <arch>aarch64</arch>
  <vcpu max='512'/>
  <os supported='yes'>
    <loader supported='yes'>
      <enum name='type'>
        <value>rom</value>
        <value>pflash</value>
      </enum>
      <enum name='readonly'>
        <value>yes</value>
        <value>no</value>
      </enum>
    </loader>
  </os>
  <cpu>
    <mode name='host-passthrough' supported='no'/>
    <mode name='host-model' supported='no'/>
    <mode name='custom' supported='yes'>
      <model usable='unknown'>pxa262</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>pxa270-a0</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>arm1136</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>cortex-a15</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>pxa260</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>arm1136-r2</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>pxa261</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>pxa255</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>cortex-a72</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>cortex-m33</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>arm926</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>cortex-r5f</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>arm11mpcore</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>pxa250</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>ti925t</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>cortex-a57</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>sa1110</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>arm1176</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>cortex-a53</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>sa1100</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>pxa270-c5</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>cortex-a9</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>cortex-a7</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>cortex-a8</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>pxa270-c0</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>arm1026</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>pxa270-b1</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>cortex-m3</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>max</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>cortex-m4</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>pxa270-b0</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>arm946</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>cortex-m0</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>cortex-r5</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>pxa270-a1</model>
      <model usable='unknown'>pxa270</model>
    </mode>
  </cpu>
  <devices>
    <disk supported='yes'>
      <enum name='diskDevice'>
        <value>disk</value>
        <value>cdrom</value>
        <value>floppy</value>
        <value>lun</value>
      </enum>
      <enum name='bus'>
        <value>fdc</value>
        <value>scsi</value>
        <value>virtio</value>
        <value>usb</value>
        <value>sata</value>
      </enum>
    </disk>
    <graphics supported='yes'>
      <enum name='type'>
        <value>sdl</value>
        <value>vnc</value>
        <value>spice</value>
      </enum>
    </graphics>
    <video supported='yes'>
      <enum name='modelType'>
        <value>vga</value>
        <value>cirrus</value>
        <value>vmvga</value>
        <value>virtio</value>
      </enum>
    </video>
    <hostdev supported='yes'>
      <enum name='mode'>
        <value>subsystem</value>
      </enum>
      <enum name='startupPolicy'>
        <value>default</value>
        <value>mandatory</value>
        <value>requisite</value>
        <value>optional</value>
      </enum>
      <enum name='subsysType'>
        <value>usb</value>
        <value>pci</value>
        <value>scsi</value>
      </enum>
      <enum name='capsType'/>
      <enum name='pciBackend'/>
    </hostdev>
  </devices>
  <features>
    <gic supported='yes'>
      <enum name='version'>
        <value>2</value>
        <value>3</value>
      </enum>
    </gic>
  </features>
</domainCapabilities>

if we dont think that is worth added custom checking for fine but i still think this shoudl at least have a workaround config option to contol."}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2020-01-21 13:07:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

by the way as noted in the bug we can actully get more detailed info form lscpu or /proc/cpuinfo which include the cpu flags and the cpu model names. although lscpu does need to be compiled with that support as it was added in 2018'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2020-03-09 20:21:00.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

Change-Id: I0ef4b954b7f4ae65b6c0f96580c5f9472a2b873c
Signed-off-by: Kevin Zhao <kevinzs2048@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 4bb54ae86981d186e41dcc325d171ab951beb7b6)

commit_message:
Skip cpu comparison on AArch64

Host CPU compatibility check does not make sense on AArch64,
this patch skips CPU comparison.

Closes-bug: #1756118

Change-Id: I0ef4b954b7f4ae65b6c0f96580c5f9472a2b873c
Signed-off-by: Kevin Zhao <kevinzs2048@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 4bb54ae86981d186e41dcc325d171ab951beb7b6)

commit_message:
Do not create temporary swift URLS for ceph-ansible

The state information in the ceph-ansible fetch directory
is no longer necessary to replace a Ceph monitor as of
ceph-ansible 4.0.14-1. Stein, Train, Ussuri and newer
should be using this version of ceph-ansible or newer.
TripleO does not need to do extra work to maintain the
fetch directory.

This means that the plan_management workbook no longer
needs to create the SwiftFetchDirGetTempurl and the
SwiftFetchDirPutTempurl parameters. This patch removes
the create_ceph_ansible_fetch_directory_backup_plan
task which creates them. It also removes the workbook
rename_ceph_ansible_fetch_directory.

Both Icce658f803a608ee4b7df34b0b8297ecabcdb0ee and
Ifab82c9a5b0a206c14ae7976d2c1c7f0e9fa3d9d are effectively
reverted of their ceph aspects with this change, but this
change should not be backported to Rocky or older because
ceph-ansible 3 still needs the fetch directory.

Unlclean cherry pick; required manual changes.

Change-Id: I167449e4d7e38f0f5fd74251a3bd8f5b0b31451b
Related-Bug: #1863809
(cherry picked from commit a54dc49bba9b31cf16416f6478d0f784b6503a9a)
(cherry picked from commit 5b363038a2329cde1cd60dbcae610b196346d714)

[{'created': '2020-03-07 14:10:31.000000000', 'message': "Enforce firewall rules before pacemaker-auth

We want to make sure that any firewall rule set to open pacemaker ports
is executed before we run any commands that invoke pcs to
authenticate remote nodes.

It simply makes sense from a high-level POV to explicitely open
up firewall rules before we invoke pcs commands that will talk to
remote nodes.

I have actually seen one case in the wild where during a scaleup
the node being scaled up was waiting on Exec['wait-for-settle']
and the bootstrap node failed to contact pcs on the scaled up node
because there the firewall rules were never opened up as it was
waiting on the 'wait-for-settle' step.

Note that we *cannot* impose the ordering via a too-generic
Firewall<||> collector because in tripleo::firewall we have

    Service<||> -> Class['tripleo::firewall::post']

and we would create a circular dependency.

Tested a queens deploy with this change and we are correctly
guaranteed to open up firewalling before invoking pcs:

commit_message:
Enforce firewall rules before pacemaker-auth

We want to make sure that any firewall rule set to open pacemaker ports
is executed before we run any commands that invoke pcs to
authenticate remote nodes.

It simply makes sense from a high-level POV to explicitely open
up firewall rules before we invoke pcs commands that will talk to
remote nodes.

I have actually seen one case in the wild where during a scaleup
the node being scaled up was waiting on Exec['wait-for-settle']
and the bootstrap node failed to contact pcs on the scaled up node
because there the firewall rules were never opened up as it was
waiting on the 'wait-for-settle' step.

Note that we *cannot* impose the ordering via a too-generic
Firewall<||> collector because in tripleo::firewall we have

    Service<||> -> Class['tripleo::firewall::post']

and we would create a circular dependency.

Tested a queens deploy with this change and we are correctly
guaranteed to open up firewalling before invoking pcs:
Mar 05 16:22:51 controller-0. puppet-user[18840]: (/Stage[main]/Tripleo::Firewall/Tripleo::Firewall::Service_rules[swift_storage]/Tripleo::Firewall::Rule[123 swift storage]/Firewall[123 swift storage ipv4]/ensure) created

[{'created': '2020-02-18 14:11:34.000000000', 'message': "Improve step task check to cater for whitespace

Currently a conditional of '(step | int) == 1' will not pass
the regex check because of the additional whitespace on either
side of the filter. There are many other whitespace variations
which could also make it fail, so rather than add a bunch of
\s* into the regex, we opt to remove all whitespace from the
string instead before doing the regex match.

This ensures that we're only running the step tasks when we
should, rather than having these tasks added into all generated
plays.

Change-Id: I589406f30f7b08bc28d05632bd97392f8b3623bf

commit_message:
Improve step task check to cater for whitespace

Currently a conditional of '(step | int) == 1' will not pass
the regex check because of the additional whitespace on either
side of the filter. There are many other whitespace variations
which could also make it fail, so rather than add a bunch of
\s* into the regex, we opt to remove all whitespace from the
string instead before doing the regex match.

This ensures that we're only running the step tasks when we
should, rather than having these tasks added into all generated
plays.

Change-Id: I589406f30f7b08bc28d05632bd97392f8b3623bf
(cherry picked from commit 307470c4ce09249a381c0c68e464d5a26c25e1e1)

commit_message:
Use only ansible for fernet key rotation

This would replace the mistral workflow used for rotating the
fernet_keys. It does not replace the existing rotate-keys.yaml
playbook, but imports it in a new playbook.

Change-Id: If3410feda79ccf5087a2ecd894ccdf5e9dba5e68

commit_message:
Check Ceph*Key value format and halt on error

The CephX keys secret is expected to have a specific format, this
adds a constraint in the templates to ensure it has the correct
format.

Change-Id: Ic12c3c287a921d696de1395bc887691c48146359
Closes-Bug: 1864185
(cherry picked from commit 0940dfd95ef64cb4d1d87edfe74374b08db9c9f2)

commit_message:
Fix debian-buster partition config

There was a lack of indentation which led to:

  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "/usr/local/bin/dib-block-device", line 11, in <module>
      sys.exit(main())
    File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/diskimage_builder/block_device/cmd.py", line 120, in main
      return bdc.main()
    File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/diskimage_builder/block_device/cmd.py", line 115, in main
      self.args.func()
    File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/diskimage_builder/block_device/cmd.py", line 30, in cmd_init
      self.bd.cmd_init()
    File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/diskimage_builder/block_device/blockdevice.py", line 260, in cmd_init
      self.config = config_tree_to_graph(self.config)
    File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/diskimage_builder/block_device/config.py", line 134, in config_tree_to_graph
      "Config entry top-level should be a single dict: %s" % entry)
  diskimage_builder.block_device.exception.BlockDeviceSetupException:
    Config entry top-level should be a single dict:
      {
        'base': 'image0',
        'partitioning': None,
        'partitions': [{'flags': ['boot', 'primary'],
          'mkfs': {'mount': {'fstab': {'options': 'defaults,nobarrier,noatime', 'fsck-passno': 1}, 'mount_point': '/'}},
          'size': '100%', 'name': 'root'}],
        'label': 'mbr'}

Note the paritioning value is None rather than a dict with those keys in
it.

Change-Id: I543222402a8e4d08cf075b2ed7f7c45d705799ca

messages:
[{'account_id': 31245, 'date': '2020-03-02 15:37:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2020-03-03 11:02:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Hello,

Thanks for these changes.

Before moving forward with these changes I prefer lets time to other oslo core to discute about them, they have more background history than me about this hot topic.

Eventlet versions had break things multiple times in the past so we need to be cautious with this kind of change.

Anyway, by waiting see my inline comments.'}, {'account_id': 31245, 'date': '2020-03-06 11:08:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2020-03-06 15:52:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

It would be nice to pull in the blacklisting from global-requirements as well while we're doing this. [{'created': '2018-10-15 20:56:36.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: don't log error if guest gone during interface detach

Similar to change I8ae352ff3eeb760c97d1a6fa9d7a59e881d7aea1, if
we're processing a network-vif-deleted event while an instance
is being deleted, the asynchronous interface detach could fail
because the guest is gone from the hypervisor. The existing code
for handling this case was using a stale guest object so this
change tries to refresh the guest from the hypervisor and if the
guest is gone, the Host.get_guest() method should raise an
InstanceNotFound exception which we just trap, log and return.

Change-Id: Ic4c870cc5078d3f7ac6b2f96f8904c2a47de418e
Closes-Bug: #1797966

commit_message:
libvirt: don't log error if guest gone during interface detach

Similar to change I8ae352ff3eeb760c97d1a6fa9d7a59e881d7aea1, if
we're processing a network-vif-deleted event while an instance
is being deleted, the asynchronous interface detach could fail
because the guest is gone from the hypervisor. The existing code
for handling this case was using a stale guest object so this
change tries to refresh the guest from the hypervisor and if the
guest is gone, the Host.get_guest() method should raise an
InstanceNotFound exception which we just trap, log and return.

Change-Id: Ic4c870cc5078d3f7ac6b2f96f8904c2a47de418e
Closes-Bug: #1797966
